body:
I still can't get the minimal example to reproduce the problem in xwayland and I can't get renderdoc to capture frames under native wayland but here is an example frame from a somewhat minimized version of the full game showing the issue in xwayland.

[example.rdc.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19477255/example.rdc.zip)

I don't fully understand what's happening here but I see that the scene has rendered as I expect it to in event 129 on the timeline but then in 134 if reverts back to the way it looked in 128, erasing the eyelid mesh that rendered in 129.
I was able to reproduce on Linux/X11 with the given example, and I have bisected the problem to #17698.

I poked at it a bit more and found that removing the morph targets from the mesh makes the symptoms go away. When the morph targets are present the correct meshes are still drawn they just aren't in the right locations.

issue.title: Buffer overrun in main_opaque_pass_3d in 0.16-rc.1

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: A-Animation
labels.description: Make things move and change over time

labels.name: S-Needs-Investigation
labels.description: This issue requires detective work to figure out what's going wrong

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## Bevy version
0.16-rc.1

## \[Optional\] Relevant system information

Linux, both wayland and xwayland, intel GPU
```ignore
AdapterInfo { name: "Intel(R) UHD Graphics 620 (KBL GT2)", vendor: 32902, device: 22807, device_type: IntegratedGpu, driver: "Intel open-source Mesa driver", driver_info: "Mesa 25.0.2-arch1.2", backend: Vulkan }
```
## What you did

I updated to 0.16-rc.1

## What went wrong

After updating to `0.16-rc.1`I began to see this crash intermittently. I see it something like 1/4 of the times I run the program, the other times it runs without any panic. It appears to always happen in the frame where I first render 3d meshes. The splash screen and loading screens, which use only 2d and UI elements have never triggered the panic.

I have removed all my custom materials and pipelines and the error still occurs.

## Additional information

I see other rendering glitches which may be related but I'm not sure. The other problem is that some, but not all, meshes flicker between being in the correct location and being offset or disappearing entirely when the camera moves. That feels to me like a problem with memory alignment or something in the bindings, which is why I think it might be related to the buffer overrun. But when I look at the frames in renderdoc it doesn't show any errors or warnings which I would expect if it really was related to alignment.

I'm still trimming my code down looking for a minimal example but I'm going to go ahead and post this now in the hopes that the problem is obvious to someone without that.

body:
Did some investigation, and was able to discover some things.

First, what's basically happening is that when meshes are getting culled on the CPU, but the mesh instance that's getting removed on the GPU is seemingly incorrect. For example:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e4600e38-10a5-4d94-97af-81bcb1b5bdf8)

I've dragged the window here to cover the bottom row, but 2 of the eyelids that get removed are on the top row. You can replicate this with any row size, for example with 10x10 we'd see 10 eyelids getting removed. However, importantly, this seems to be pretty deterministic. When I restart the program, the same eyelids are always removed.

This suggests there's some kind of indexing error in how our mesh instances are getting written out to the GPU. I've confirmed that the instances we keep on the CPU are correct, and so I'm not totally sure what's happening.

It's also possible to break things more extremely:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1678f33f-582d-4c63-b067-b49e9cf9eef9)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4f44ed46-ed2b-45e7-839e-b7a91a5b8d4c)

This happens when resizing the windows such that all of the meshes are culled. Even when moving pretty slowly, they can be left in states with weird broken transforms.

Have to stop here for tonight.

@alec-deason Would you mind uploading the version without morph targets?

Sure. This is exactly the same model except that I deleted all the shape keys in blender and reexported it.

[eye.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19539338/eye.zip)

issue.body:
# Objective

Fixes #18550.

Because bin state for unbatchable meshes wasn't being cleared each frame, the buffer indices for unbatchable meshes would demote from sparse to dense storage and aggressively leak memory, with all kinds of weird consequences downstream, namely supplying invalid instance ranges for render.

## Solution

Clear out the unbatchable mesh bin state when we start a new frame.
